According to Giske, none of these compounds were detected in samples taken at Elvåga in 2024. – In samples from Maridalsvannet, we have found a few of these (3 out of 17), but these are very low values that are well below the prescribed limit value for PFAS compounds in the new drinking water regulations. Giske tells Faktisk.no that the water quality is safe and is continuously monitored.Drinking water not the main sourceShe says that the most important source of PFAS for humans is the food we eat. This is also stated by the EU's EFSA, which carries out risk assessments on the levels of PFAS that humans can ingest. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen at NIVA therefore believes that it is generally not necessary to use a reverse osmosis filter in Norway. – To reduce exposure to PFAS, it is recommended to be aware of which products you buy and surround yourself with. Products marked with the Nordic Ecolabel guarantee to be free of PFAS, says Gundersen.The researcher believes that places where such a filter might be appropriate are at private water sources, such as a well, located near a firefighting training area or at places where PFAS has previously been produced. But Gundersen adds that the water utility is responsible for ensuring that public water supplies are of sufficiently good quality.

headline: These videos are going viral – but they don't show what you think
summary: Old videos are being spread on social media in the wake of the attacks between Iran and Israel.
text: This is the fact-check :On the night of Sunday, June 22, the United States bombed the three Iranian nuclear facilities of Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan.While the United States claims the attacks have put Iran's nuclear program out of action , Iranian authorities deny that the damage is serious.At the same time, social media is flooded with dramatic videos purporting to show the attacks.But many of these clips turn out to be from completely different times and events.A widely shared video purports to show the US attack on the Fordow facility over the weekend. View the archived version here .On TikTok, one of the posts has received 1.5 million views and over 40,000 likes.This video does not show US attacks on Iran. Screenshot: TikTok.But the video probably shows a Ukrainian attack on a Russian ammunition depot in September 2024.We found this out using a reverse image search on Google.The attack took place in the city of Toropets in the Tver region, western Russia, and was so powerful that it  affected seismometers in Norway .The video was first shared on social media, and has not been verified, according to  Reuters .Both international and Norwegian media used the video in connection with the Ukrainian attack, including  NRK ,  TV2 ,  The Guardian  and  CNN .We also made a TikTok video about this fact check. Watch it here .Another video also purports to show the Fordow attack, according to several on social media.This video has received many views on TikTok, but does not show what is claimed. Screenshot: TikTok.But a reverse image search shows that the video has been shared several times in December 2024, including by Belgian EU MP  Marc Botenga on X.It allegedly shows an Israeli attack on the Syrian coastal city of Tartus, in the wake of the fall of the Assad regime.Several media outlets, including  the Daily Mail , used the video in their coverage of the Israeli attack.Another video that is being shared frequently is claimed to show Iranian attacks against Israel.Several on social media claim that this video shows Iranian attacks against Israel. Screenshot: TikTok.Using reverse image search, we find the video on YouTube with an Arabic title.The translated title shows that the video is from the celebration of the Algerian football club Mouloudia Club's 103rd anniversary.A simple Google search for the club's name and "103 years" yields several hits on posts with the same video from the celebration.

headline: The Swedish Diabetes Association is being exploited to sell fraudulent anti-obesity drugs
summary: The Swedish Diabetes Association is being used in scam ads where the scammers claim to have a miracle cure for weight loss. “Total fake,” says Fredrik Nyström, professor of internal medicine at Linköping University.
text: This is the fact-check :A Facebook page claiming to be the Swedish Diabetes Association has posted a before and after photo along with a sad story about two sisters.In the first photo, they are sitting on a sofa with a friend and smiling at the camera. In the second photo, one of the sisters has been replaced by a photo. She has died, only 52 years old.According to the story, the sisters have struggled with their weight for a long time.Kajsa and I have always been the big girls. "Even in school we knew how to pose to look slimmer - to hold our shirts in front of our stomachs.People said: "You have such a beautiful face."And we pretended not to hear.I remember when Kajsa was tying her shoes at Target, and could barely breathe when she got up.She laughed it off: "I'm just old."I laughed along, but something inside me froze.Then the call came. I was in the grocery store buying toilet paper.Diana called. "Kajsa fainted. Heart attack. She passed out."But, writes the "Diabetesf�rbundet", with the help of a dietary supplement, the remaining sister managed to lose weight and in the after picture she really does look slimmer.The post has received over 1,200 likes in two weeks.For anyone who clicks on “Diabetesf�rbundet” and examines the Facebook page, it superficially looks like it could belong to the real Swedish Diabetes Association.There are Swedish address and contact details and the link leads to the real association's website . However, the scammers have only made a copy. Their Facebook page has just over 900 followers and if you search Facebook's search function for Diabetesförbundet you will find the real organization, with 16,000 followers.The Swedish Diabetes Association neither recommends, certifies nor endorses products, services or medicines, writes Bjørn Ehlin, chairman of the real interest organization, to the Source Criticism Agency:In 2025, we have seen an increase in the number of advertisements on social media where advertisers use the names and logos of various organizations and authorities without permission, including the Swedish Diabetes Association and the Swedish Medical Products Agency.We take seriously the creation of accounts and pages on social media with our name and logo, as well as websites We take seriously the creation of accounts and pages on social media with our name and logo, as well as websites/online shops that use our name, logo and material from our website with the aim of making the visitor/buyer believe that we are behind it.We would like to urge everyone to be attentive and critical of the source when they see advertisements on social media. Advertisements with claims that “seem too good to be true” are usually that.From an email from the Swedish Diabetes AssociationThe link that the scammers want you to click on leads to a site with the Swedish Diabetes Association's logo. There you are offered to buy ten bottles of the dietary supplement for 700 kronor and are promised a weight loss of 60 kilos.Scam site.The image of the women appears to have been created using AI and has not been published elsewhere online. Here's our guide on how to investigate a suspicious Facebook post !Fake profiles pepper the comments sectionIn the comments section, there are many people who confirm the weight loss claims and post before and after pictures of themselves. However, if you search with, for example, Google's image search function Lens, it turns out that the pictures are taken from various weight loss success stories online."Look at me! I've really lost weight! This picture says more than I can ever explain," writes a woman who is said to be called Maja Karlsson and lives in Borlänge.Fake profile on Facebook.But Maja's before and after photo belongs to a woman in another part of the world who in April shared her weight loss with the help of the drug Mounjaro on the Reddit forum.Search with Google Lens.Maja's Facebook profile only contains a picture of herself, an illustration, and her friends appear to be from various Asian countries.The same goes for "Elin Andersson" who claims in the thread that she got amazing results for a cheap price. Even her before and after pictures are stolen from Reddit.Comment on Facebook June 4.The “cloned” page is controlled from Hong Kong and China, among other places, which may explain why the fake profiles have a “friendship” exclusively from Asian countries.When examining the Facebook page further, it is also discovered that it was started in 2023 as “The KING Photography”, and changed its name to “Diabetesförbundet” only in April this year.From the page transparency section of the scammers' Facebook page.Here you will learn more about how to check out a Facebook page and its ads .Can a pill make you lose weight?The answer is yes, there is – but no, this product that the scammers want to sell you does not have those properties.– There are no dietary supplements that have these effects, it is a total fake, says Fredrik Nyström, a professor who researches risk factors for cardiovascular disease, obesity and diabetes at Linköping University.He is supported by Professor Åke Lernmark, senior professor in experimental diabetes at Lund University.– After many years of miracle pills, we have all learned that dietary supplements such as pills do not lead to weight loss, he tells Källkritikbyrån.However, there are now medications where patients lose weight using pills or injections.More scam ads from the same sender on Facebook.The fake drug in the ad is said to have the same mechanics as the high-profile drugs that have appeared in recent years, which regulate blood sugar and affect hunger signals to the brain.But Fredrik Nyström dismisses the idea that this dietary supplement would have those properties.– If it existed, it would be as well-known as possible. There is no chance that pharmaceutical companies would miss a preparation that is just a dietary supplement or some natural product, they would have bought it up a long time ago. You can always just count on it being fake if it is claimed that you will lose 20 kilos with this dietary supplement.Nyström is concerned that the fake ads are spreading and that the fraudsters are using increasingly technologically advanced methods.– It's a new and difficult chapter. People are really going for it!Åke Lernmark at Lund University thinks the hoax campaign is regrettable.– It's tragic that so many are easily fooled and that manufacturers of dietary supplements are more or less unscrupulous.More scam ads from the same sender on Facebook.Björn Ehlin, chairman of the Swedish Diabetes Association, urges you to talk to your doctor.– It is claimed that it does not affect other medications, but there is always a risk that dietary supplements can have an impact depending on the content and which medication you are taking. So you should always check with your doctor whether the particular dietary supplement you are thinking of taking has an impact on the medications you are taking.Uses experts and authoritiesThe fake “Diabetesförbundet” has had 18 active ad campaigns on Facebook since the beginning of May, with various made-up stories and stolen images.Several public figures, such as various Swedish heart and obesity researchers, and Olivia Wigzell, Director General of the Public Health Agency, have been exploited by the scammers in the ads.Fake profile on Facebook.Fredrik Nyström, a professor at Linköping University, has himself been affected.– They have faked advertisements with me that are very similar to this theme. “For this many hundreds a month you will lose this much weight”. And that's me in the picture, there are even films sometimes.Källkritikbyrån has previously reported on how Lars Wallentin, a senior professor of cardiology in Uppsala, was deep-faked, i.e. remade with AI in a film . The purpose there has also been to market various dietary supplements.
